X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=MhU_FjEHJT4j9b-67EPwoQyy3xrR0AnacA2WZcNgwtLh1tYjedYZrJDDPA

Hi Jeff, 

I am glad that you like my program and enjoy it! :) 

I know it =
would be cool to browse the archive, or have an external 
routine that quer=
ies the archive by different criteria to show me 
what was achieved during =
the run, but this program now is actually a 
stepping stone for another res=
earch project I have, evolving leaky-
integrator substrates by HyperNEAT co=
mbined with evolving the 
substrate itself, all used in one Alife simulatio=
n of mass-spring 
creatures, sensing collision and reacting by contracting =
the springs. 
And all this with Novelty Search searching for new and new be=
haviors. 
I believe that this is a pretty serious test of how far complexit=
y 
can go in such open-ended domain. I can later mix it with fitness 
searc=
h once a good population has evolved, on objectives 
like "swimming". 

Let=
 me mention about one interesting experiment I made with the NS 
NEVH. I re=
stricted the substrate connectivity so that output->output 
connections are=
 not queried. Then I made the environment to 0 gravity 
and removed the gro=
und plane. The behavior characterization was 
changed like this. The behavi=
or data is a vector of 15 doubles 
representing the outputs. Each time an o=
utput oscillates (going to 
+treshold and then -treshold, or vice versa), i=
ts corresponding place 
in the vector is incremented. 
So the vector is act=
ually counting how many oscillations the outputs 
did during the lifetime. =
A substrate oscillating with high frequency 
is very far in the behavior sp=
ace. Different outputs oscillating are 
counted too. The behavior distance =
metric is the eucledian distance 
between these 15-D vectors. 

So novelty =
search now has to find new ways to oscillate the entire 
body, to do repeat=
ing movements. In all the runs, Novelty Search with 
HyperNEAT finds walkin=
g gaits 100% of the time, in the first 1000 
evaluations. There are also sw=
imming gaits and all kind of stuff (I 
saw one individual actually dancing =
:)) 

So what was stopping it from walking before, is the gravity. Keeping =

balance on one leg and trying to walk at the same time turns out to 
be ve=
ry hard task. One environmental constraint that would be useful 
to make it=
 walk is, when only one foot has stepped on the ground, 
stick that foot to=
 the ground. So the chance the humanoid to fall is 
minimized. 

As for the=
 novelty search stagnation, where getting new behaviors 
becomes hard, the =
population begins to do something like a random 
probing anything that is n=
ot the same stuff. Then it begins to rely 
entirely on mutation to get out =
somehow. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrot=
e:
>
> I finally borrowed a windows machine from someone and looked at 
thi=
s. It's
> really fun to watch! I am leaving it running overnight to see wha=
t 
happens.
> So far the best I have seen has been about a five mini-step s=
huffle
> backwards...although I have seen a few three mini-step forward 
sh=
uffles.
> 
> Can you post either the genome and or a movie of the best org =

you've seen so
> far? 
> 
> I second the notion that it would be cool to b=
rowse the archive, 
especially
> if you could choose archive members to vie=
w based on max distance 
from 0,0
> or something like that.
> 
> It might h=
elp you to visualize things if you added another viewing 
mode that
> put a=
 dot in the 3D viewer for every x,y,z coordinate in the 
archive (one
> col=
or) and in the current population (another color).
> 
> Watching this also =
makes me wonder about the population losing its 
gradient
> and disengaging=
. Here is the potential concern (and I think mattias 
and ken
> discussed t=
his already): Once all the easy to access points are 
found, if
> most of t=
he orgs are not getting somewhere new, they will all have 
equal
> fitnesse=
s and the search will not be focused on the outside edge. 
Do you
> think t=
his is happening (and might this be why David mentioned that 
he saw a
> lo=
t of repeats toward the end)? The visualization I just proposed 
might help=

> on this front. Do the points added in the archive tend to be 
further an=
d
> further away from 0,0....or is it just filling in the spaces in the 
ne=
arby
> vicinity? 
> 
> Despite these concerns/suggestions, it is very fun s=
tuff to look 
at...and
> its exciting that you are hybridizing these ideas =
so quickly and 
testing
> them. 
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital =
Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> 
> jclune@...
> 
> 
> 
>

om: David D'Ambrosio <ddambro84@...>

neat@yahoogroups.com>

 uploaded to neat
> > 
> > Wow, this looks really cool Petar.  I thought it=
 would be awhile
> > before we saw HyperNEAT and novelty search combined.  =
I ran it 
while I
> > was working on other stuff for a bit over 50,000 eval=
uations, 
checking
> > in on it periodically.  The behavioral diversity was=
 really
> > impressive: I got guys that were taking baby steps and guys tha=
t 
were
> > doing yoga poses (I swear one of them did "the chair"), althoug=
h 
there
> > were still a good number of repeats, especially near the end 
=
(falling
> > onto theirs knees seemed pretty common).  No one that I saw ha=
d a 
good
> > walking gait, but I guess it's possible that one could have w=
hen I
> > wasn't watching, perhaps we need an option to browse the archive.=
 
I'm
> > curious about a few things, if you wouldn't mind sharing:
> > 
> =
> -What did you use as a novelty metric?  It's seems like there are 
a
> > =
number of viable options here.
> > 
> > -What do the nodes on the substrate=
 mean, and are they just on a 
flat
> > plane?  I used your older version w=
hen it was first released, and 
if I
> > remember right the two on the left=
 are inputs and the stuff on the
> > right is various joints, but I wanted =
to make sure.
> > 
> > -Similarly, what do you use as the 5th input on the =
CPPN?
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > David D'Ambrosio
> > 
> > 
> > 
> >
